‚≠ê Boys and girls who are praised for their effort and good behaviour will want to keep behaving well and keep receiving praise. 

4Ô∏è‚É£ Here are 4 simple tips for praising @fields.child_nickname:

1Ô∏è‚É£ SEE IT

üëÄ Look for anything good or helpful @fields.child_nickname does.

‚è∏ Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive.

3Ô∏è‚É£ REPEAT IT

üå∑ Look for something to praise @fields.child_nickname for every day.
üî∂ Even if it is something really small, keep doing it.

actions.text: This lesson is about creating routines for spending one-on-one time with @fields.child_nickname. üîÑ
{F2_GRANDFATHER} includes one-on-one time with her granddaughter as part of her bedtime routine, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. Let‚Äôs see how they do it together!

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your blocks, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. When I come back, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can have 5 minutes of One-on-One Time together.

{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Okay!
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: Time to get ready for bed. First, let‚Äôs get you nice and clean with a bath.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: You were so well-behaved in the bath, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. Now it is time to put in your bedclothes.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: Well done for getting in your pants all by yourself, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}! Now you brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth!

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: You were so cooperative while getting ready for bed! Now we have 5 minutes of One-on-One time to spend together. What would you like to do?

{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Yay! Can you read me my favourite story?

{F2_GRANDFATHER}: ‚ÄúThe end‚Ä¶.‚Äù Such a lovely story! Goodnight my darling girl. I love you very much.

{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Goodnight, Grandpa

1Ô∏è‚É£ LEARN
üí° Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:  
üòÉHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.  
üòîSad: Something important in your life needs attention.
üî¥Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
üò£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
üëÄSurprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
üö©Afraid: Run away from danger.
üé® As girls and boys get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Noticing our own emotions helps us make clear decisions and act in a nurturing way with @fields.child_nickname and ourselves.

‚≠ê Noticing and Talking about feelings with @fields.child_nickname will help them learn how to express and regulate themselves. 

üëåThey will learn that all feelings are okay - even the unpleasant ones.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help @fields.child_nickname learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in @fields.child_nickname.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.  
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
üíô Noticing can also allow girls and boys to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN
Be open, notice üëÄ, and listen üëÇ to @fields.child_nickname when they share how they are feeling. 
üíõ Accept how you and @fields.child_nickname feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.

4Ô∏è‚É£TALK

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

‚≠ê When @fields.child_nickname is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you didn‚Äôt get to play outside?‚Äù
You can also help @fields.child_nickname learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game

5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE

üòÉ Share your own feelings with @fields.child_nickname. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldn‚Äôt go out when I wanted to. 

 üéàThis sets a good example and shows @fields.child_nickname that it's okay to share their own feelings.

6Ô∏è‚É£CARE

üå∑ Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. 

‚≠êJump with your boy or girl a little bit to shake out anger or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

üíö Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

Home Activity! During one-on-one time today, notice @fields.child_nickname‚Äôs feelings. Talk to @fields.child_nickname by describing both your own feelings and the feelings of @fields.child_nickname.

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in your girl.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.  
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.

actions.text: This lesson is about how we can stay calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our girls and boys. üíö

As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

üå∑ We love our girls and boys, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

üí° It is important for us to try to stay calm in order to help manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
Let‚Äôs do a True/False quiz:
When I am angry at my boy or girl, I should show that I am angry so they stop misbehaving.

üëÄOops! Good Try!

üíõ It can be very difficult when your girl or boy is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and check your anger before doing anything. 

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

üéâ That‚Äôs correct! 

üíõ It can be very difficult when your boy or girl is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and check your anger before doing anything. 

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.
Sorry, I dont' understand what you mean.

There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CLEAR*

‚úÖ Rather than saying what you DON‚ÄôT want, tell your boy or girl what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

‚ú® ‚ÄúPlease speak more softly.‚Äù

‚ú® ‚ÄúRemember to walk inside the house.‚Äù

Hay cuatro pasos para mantener la calma en situaciones de estr√©s: MANTENER LA CALMA, SER R√ÅPIDO, SER CLARO y SER POSITIVO.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *SER CLARO*

1Ô∏è‚É£ LEARN
üí° Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:
üòÉHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.
üòîSad: Something important in your life needs attention.
üî¥Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
üò£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
üëÄSurprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
üö©Afraid: Run away from danger.
üé® As teens, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Well done, You have now learnt the 6 steps to Noticing Feelings during one-on-one time! ‚≠ê You have completed @(fields.c_n_mod_compl +1) out of @fields.c_n_mod lessons in the course, Improve my Relationship with my Teen.

Noticing and Talking about feelings with @fields.child_nickname will help them learn how to express themselves. 

üëåThey will learn that all feelings are okay - even the unpleasant ones.
 
üå∑ You can help by listening to them, thinking about how it must feel for them, and accepting their emotions. 

ü§óThis will help them recognise other people‚Äôs feelings, too.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help @fields.child_nickname learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in @fields.child_nickname.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
üíô Noticing can also allow your teen to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN
Be open, notice üëÄ, and listen üëÇ to @fields.child_nickname when they share how they are feeling. 
üíõ Accept how you and @fields.child_nickname feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.

4Ô∏è‚É£TALK

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

‚≠ê When @fields.child_nickname is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre pacing around the house, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you can‚Äôt go out at night?‚Äù
You can also help @fields.child_nickname learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game

5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE

üòÉ Share your own feelings with @fields.child_nickname. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldn‚Äôt go out when I wanted to. 

 üéàThis sets a good example and shows @fields.child_nickname that it's okay to share their own feelings.

6Ô∏è‚É£CARE

üå∑ Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. 

‚≠ê Do some active exercise to shake out anger, give some space to each other or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

üíö Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN

üíõ Accept how you and your adolescent feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.

4Ô∏è‚É£TALK

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

‚≠ê When your adolescent is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre pacing around the house, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you can‚Äôt go out at night?‚Äù
You can also help your adolescent learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game

5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE

üòÉ Share your own feelings with your adolescent. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldn‚Äôt go out when I wanted to. 

 üéàThis sets a good example and shows your adolescent that it's okay to share their own feelings.

6Ô∏è‚É£CARE

üå∑ Use physical and verbal support to make your adolescent feel accepted and loved. 

‚≠ê Do some active exercise to shake out anger, give some space to each other or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

üíö Remind your adolescent that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in your girl.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
üíô Noticing can also allow your teen to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

actions.text: This skill is about how we can keep calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our teens. üíö

As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

üå∑ We love our teens, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

üí° It is important for us to stay in control and manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
Let‚Äôs do a quiz!
True or False: When I am angry at my teen, I should show that I am angry so that they stop misbehaving.

üëÄ Oops! Good Try!

üíõ It can be very difficult when your teen is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and regulate your own anger before doing anything. 

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

üéâ That‚Äôs correct! 

üíõ It can be very difficult when your teen is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and control your own anger before doing anything. 

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CLEAR*

‚úÖ Rather than saying what you DON‚ÄôT want, tell your teen what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

‚ú® ‚ÄúPlease speak more softly.‚Äù

‚ú® ‚ÄúRemember to hang your jacket in your closet, please.‚Äù 

This way, it is easier for them to follow! ‚≠ê

4Ô∏è‚É£ *BE POSITIVE*

‚úÖ Praise your teen when they behave well!

‚úÖ Redirecting your teen to a positive behaviour will help you manage the situation.

‚úÖ It will also help them know what you expect from them!

‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚¨úÔ∏è

Can you share these tips today?

‚úÖRemember your goal: make @fields.child_nickname feel loved and secure.

‚úÖAct effectively: Take a pause or a few breaths before asking @fields.child_nickname to do something else.

‚úÖ Speak with @fields.child_nickname in a calm voice.

2Ô∏è‚É£ *BE QUICK*

‚è∞ There are other things you can do to help manage unwanted behaviour before it becomes stressful. 

‚ú®Praise something positive that your teen did today. 

‚ú®Understand their feelings. For example, it may feel boring to clean up after having fun or ending a big task. 

‚ú®Ask your teen to do something else, and distract them before the unwanted behaviour begins or gets worse. 

‚ú®Invite @fields.child_nickname in a chore you are doing. You can ask @fields.child_nickname to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently. 

üí° This is much easier than using consequences after they do something!

text: Esta habilidad consiste en aprender a mantener la calma y controlar nuestro enojo cuando enfrentamos situaciones estresantes con nuestros adolescentes. üíö

Cuando empezaste a identificar los sentimientos y las emociones, debes haber notado ciertos sentimientos como los de enojo, frustraci√≥n o tristeza. 

üå∑ Aunque amamos a nuestros adolescentes, el estr√©s de cuidarlos y otros eventos del d√≠a a d√≠a pueden hacer que nos enojemos. ¬°Esto es parte de la vida! 

üí° Es importante que intentemos mantener la calma para poder controlar nuestro enojo y evitar lastimar o herir a los dem√°s.

1Ô∏è‚É£ LEARN
üí° Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:  
üòÉHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.  
üòîSad: Something important in your life needs attention.
üî¥Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
üò£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
üëÄSurprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
üö©Afraid: Run away from danger.
üé® As girls and boys get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Noticing our own emotions helps us make clear decisions and act in a nurturing way with @fields.child_nickname and ourselves.

‚≠ê Noticing and Talking about feelings with @fields.child_nickname will help them learn how to express and regulate themselves. 

üëåThey will learn that all feelings are okay - even the unpleasant ones.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help @fields.child_nickname learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in @fields.child_nickname.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.  
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
üíô Noticing can also allow girls and boys to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN
Be open, notice üëÄ, and listen üëÇ to @fields.child_nickname when they share how they are feeling. 
üíõ Accept how you and @fields.child_nickname feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.

4Ô∏è‚É£TALK

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

‚≠ê When @fields.child_nickname is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you didn‚Äôt get to play outside?‚Äù
You can also help @fields.child_nickname learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game

5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE

üòÉ Share your own feelings with @fields.child_nickname. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldn‚Äôt go out when I wanted to. 

 üéàThis sets a good example and shows @fields.child_nickname that it's okay to share their own feelings.

6Ô∏è‚É£CARE

üå∑ Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. 

‚≠êJump with your boy or girl a little bit to shake out anger or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

üíö Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

actions.text: This lesson is about how we can stay calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our girls and boys. üíö

As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

üå∑ We love our girls and boys, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

üí° It is important for us to try to stay calm in order to help manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} is about to spend one-on-one time with {F2_SON_8} but finds the living room is a mess. He notices that this makes her feel angry.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I‚Äôm feeling really angry. I am tired and my head feels hot. My mouth and throat are tight. I just want to shout at {F2_SON_8}.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I will Take a Pause and put on my favorite song.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I am feeling a little better. I can think more clearly about what to do to support my little boy.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: {F2_SON_8}, very good job doing your homework. You might be feeling tired now. Let's take a 5-minute break, and after that, we can play a game together to quickly pick up the toys.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: Thank you for doing your part to keep the house clean, {F2_SON_8}.i! I‚Äôm so proud of your effort.  Oh! It is our one-on-one time. What would you like to do?

When I am angry at my boy or girl, I should show that I am angry so they stop misbehaving.

üëÄOops! Good Try!

üíõ It can be very difficult when your girl or boy is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and check your anger before doing anything. 

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

1Ô∏è‚É£ BE CALM
2Ô∏è‚É£ BE QUICK
3Ô∏è‚É£ BE CLEAR
4Ô∏è‚É£ BE POSITIVE
There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CLEAR*

‚úÖ Rather than saying what you DON‚ÄôT want, tell your boy or girl what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

‚ú® ‚ÄúPlease speak more softly.‚Äù

‚ú® ‚ÄúRemember to walk inside the house.‚Äù

This way, it is easier for them to follow! ‚≠ê

4Ô∏è‚É£ *BE POSITIVE*

‚úÖ Praise your girl or boy when they behave well!

‚úÖ Redirecting your boy or girl to a positive behaviour will help you manage the situation.

‚úÖ It will also help them know what you expect from them!

1Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CALM*

‚úÖ Be aware of your own feelings.

‚úÖTake care of your emotions.

‚úÖRemember your goal: make @fields.child_nickname feel loved and secure.

‚úÖAct effectively: Take a pause or a few breaths before asking @fields.child_nickname to do something else.

‚úÖ Speak with @fields.child_nickname in a calm voice.

2Ô∏è‚É£ *BE QUICK*

‚è∞ There are other things you can do to help manage unwanted behavior before it becomes stressful. 

‚ú®Praise something positive that your boy or girl did today. 

‚ú®Understand their feelings. For example, it may feel boring to pick up toys after having fun or ending a big task. 


‚ú®Ask your girl or boy to do something else, and distract them before the unwanted behaviour begins or gets worse. 


‚ú®Invite @fields.child_nickname in a chore you are doing. You can ask @fields.child_nickname to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently. 


üí° This is much easier than using consequences after they do something!

text: Esta lecci√≥n trata sobre c√≥mo podemos mantener la calma y controlar nuestro enojo cuando enfrentamos situaciones estresantes con nuestros ni√±os y ni√±as. üíö

Cuando empezaste a identificar los sentimientos y las emociones, debes haber notado ciertos sentimientos como los de enojo, frustraci√≥n o tristeza. 

üå∑ Aunque amamos a nuestras ni√±as y ni√±os, el estr√©s de cuidarlos y otros eventos del d√≠a a d√≠a pueden hacer que nos enojemos. ¬°Esto es parte de la vida! 

üí° Es importante que intentemos mantener la calma para poder controlar nuestro enojo y evitar lastimar o herir a los dem√°s.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} est√° a punto de pasar un tiempo Uno a Uno con {F2_SON_8}, pero en el camino ve que la sala est√° hecha un desastre. Se da cuenta de que esto le molesta y le hace sentir enojo.

{F2_GRANDFATHER} (en su pensamiento): Estoy molesto y me estoy sintiendo enojado. Estoy cansado y siento la cabeza caliente. Mi boca y mi garganta se sienten tensas. Solo quiero gritarle a {F2_SON_8}.

1Ô∏è‚É£ LEARN
üí° Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:
üòÉHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.
üòîSad: Something important in your life needs attention.
üî¥Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
üò£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
üëÄSurprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
üö©Afraid: Run away from danger.
üé® As teens, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

Noticing and Talking about feelings with @fields.child_nickname will help them learn how to express themselves. 

üëåThey will learn that all feelings are okay - even the unpleasant ones.
 
üå∑ You can help by listening to them, thinking about how it must feel for them, and accepting their emotions. 

ü§óThis will help them recognise other people‚Äôs feelings, too.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help @fields.child_nickname learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE

2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
üëÄ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in @fields.child_nickname.
üòÉüòíüòîüò£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.
 
üòÉ You can also notice pleasant emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
üíô Noticing can also allow your teen to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN
Be open, notice üëÄ, and listen üëÇ to @fields.child_nickname when they share how they are feeling. 
üíõ Accept how you and @fields.child_nickname feel. Remember your and their bodies are sending messages about what you both are feeling. Recognize that feelings are important for both.

4Ô∏è‚É£TALK

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. 

üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

‚≠ê When @fields.child_nickname is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 
‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre pacing around the house, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you can‚Äôt go out at night?‚Äù
You can also help @fields.child_nickname learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game

5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE

üòÉ Share your own feelings with @fields.child_nickname. 

For example, I would feel the same way if I couldn‚Äôt go out when I wanted to. 

 üéàThis sets a good example and shows @fields.child_nickname that it's okay to share their own feelings.

6Ô∏è‚É£CARE

üå∑ Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. 

‚≠ê Do some active exercise to shake out anger, give some space to each other or take some deep breaths to calm down. These are some of the ways to deal with your emotions. 

üíö Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

actions.text: This skill is about how we can keep calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our teens. üíö

As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

üå∑ We love our teens, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

üí° It is important for us to stay in control and manage our anger so we do not hurt others.

üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.

There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CLEAR*

‚úÖ Rather than saying what you DON‚ÄôT want, tell your teen what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

‚ú® ‚ÄúPlease speak more softly.‚Äù

‚ú® ‚ÄúRemember to hang your jacket in your closet, please.‚Äù

text: Esta habilidad consiste en aprender a mantener la calma y controlar nuestro enojo cuando enfrentamos situaciones estresantes con nuestros adolescentes. üíö

Cuando empezaste a identificar los sentimientos y las emociones, debes haber notado ciertos sentimientos como los de enojo, frustraci√≥n o tristeza. 

üå∑ Aunque amamos a nuestros adolescentes, el estr√©s de cuidarlos y otros eventos del d√≠a a d√≠a pueden hacer que nos enojemos. ¬°Esto es parte de la vida! 

üí° Es importante que intentemos mantener la calma para poder controlar nuestro enojo y evitar lastimar o herir a los dem√°s.

{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: {F2_SON_15}, muy buen trabajo haciendo tu tarea. Puede que ya te sientas cansado. Vamos a descansar 5 minutos, y despu√©s de eso, podemos recoger este tiradero juntos.
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: ¬°Gracias por hacer tu parte para que la casa est√© limpia, {F2_SON_15}! Estoy muy orgullosa de tu esfuerzo. Es nuestro tiempo Uno a Uno. ¬øQu√© quieres hacer?

Hay cuatro pasos para mantener la calma en situaciones de estr√©s: MANTENER LA CALMA, SER R√ÅPIDO, SER CLARO y SER POSITIVO.

3Ô∏è‚É£ *SER CLARO*

‚úÖ En vez de decir lo que NO quieres, dile a tu adolescente lo que S√ç quieres que haga.

Por ejemplo, dile:

‚ú® "Por favor, habla m√°s bajito."

‚ú® "Acu√©rdate de colgar tu chamarra en el cl√≥set, por favor."

4Ô∏è‚É£ *SER POSITIVO*

‚úÖ ¬°Reconoce y halaga a tu adolescente cuando se porte bien!

‚úÖ ¬°Tambi√©n le ayudar√° a saber lo que esperas de √©l o ella!

1Ô∏è‚É£ *MANTENER LA CALMA*

‚úÖ S√© consciente de tus propios sentimientos.

‚úÖ Usa un tono de voz tranquilo cuando hables con @fields.child_nickname.

2Ô∏è‚É£ *SER R√ÅPIDO*

‚è∞ Hay otras cosas que puedes hacer para ayudar a controlar el comportamiento no deseado antes de que detone una situaci√≥n estresante. 

‚ú® Reconoce algo positivo que tu adolescente haya hecho hoy. 

‚ú®Comprende sus sentimientos. Por ejemplo, puede que recoger o limpiar despu√©s de divertirse o de terminar una actividad pesada se sienta como algo muy aburrido. 

‚ú®P√≠dele a tu adolescente que haga otra cosa, y genera una distracci√≥n antes de que empiece o empeore el comportamiento no deseado. 

‚ú®Invita a @fields.child_nickname a que te ayude con algo en la casa que t√∫ ya est√©s haciendo. Puedes pedirle a @fields.child_nickname que te d√© ideas de formas divertidas, r√°pidas y diferentes de hacer las tareas del hogar. 

üí° ¬°Esto es mucho m√°s f√°cil que usar consecuencias negativas despu√©s de que hacen algo!
